title: Isaiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 28.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:1, who are called the crown of pride?
options: The drunkards of Ephraim
The priests of Jerusalem
The kings of Judah
The prophets of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The drunkards of Ephraim
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:1 states 'Woe to the crown of pride, to the drunkards of Ephraim,' directly identifying them as the crown of pride.

questions.question: What will the Lord send as described in Isaiah 28:2?
options: A tempest of hail and a destroying storm
A gentle rain to nourish the land
A fire to consume the wicked
A peaceful wind to calm the sea
questions.correctAnswer: A tempest of hail and a destroying storm
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:2 describes the Lord sending 'a tempest of hail and a destroying storm, as a flood of mighty waters overflowing'.

questions.question: What will happen to the crown of pride and the drunkards of Ephraim according to Isaiah 28:3?
options: They shall be trodden under feet
They shall be exalted
They shall be blessed
They shall be healed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be trodden under feet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:3 clearly says, 'The crown of pride, the drunkards of Ephraim, shall be trodden under feet'.

questions.question: In Isaiah 28:5, the LORD of hosts will be for the residue of his people what?
options: A crown of glory and for a diadem of beauty
A pillar of fire and smoke
A shepherd and a guide
A rock and fortress
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of glory and for a diadem of beauty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:5 states the LORD shall be 'for a crown of glory, and for a diadem of beauty' to the residue of his people.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:7, who are said to err through wine and strong drink?
options: The priest and the prophet
The farmers and the merchants
The kings and the soldiers
The elders and the scribes
questions.correctAnswer: The priest and the prophet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:7 mentions that 'the priest and the prophet have erred through strong drink'.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 28:8 says all tables are full of purity and cleanliness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:8 states 'all tables are full of vomit and filthiness', indicating impurity, not cleanliness.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:9, whom will God teach knowledge?
options: Them that are weaned from the milk
The unlearned and ignorant
The kings and rulers
The children only
questions.correctAnswer: Them that are weaned from the milk
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:9 asks 'Whom shall he teach knowledge? ... them that are weaned from the milk'.

questions.question: What phrase is repeated in Isaiah 28:10 to describe how instruction is given?
options: Precept upon precept, line upon line
Love one another, peace be with you
Judge not, forgive always
Sing praises, give thanks
questions.correctAnswer: Precept upon precept, line upon line
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:10 repeats 'precept upon precept, line upon line; here a little, and there a little'.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 28:12 says the people accepted the rest and refreshing God offered.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:12 states 'yet they would not hear', showing the people rejected the rest and refreshing.

questions.question: What did the rulers in Jerusalem say according to Isaiah 28:15?
options: We have made a covenant with death and with hell
We will trust in the Lord forever
We shall follow the commandments
We will protect the poor
questions.correctAnswer: We have made a covenant with death and with hell
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:15 quotes the rulers: 'We have made a covenant with death, and with hell are we at agreement'.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:16, what has the Lord laid in Zion?
options: A tried stone, a precious corner stone
A golden crown for the king
A river of living water
A tree of life
questions.correctAnswer: A tried stone, a precious corner stone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16 says, 'I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone'.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 28:18 states the covenant with death and agreement with hell will stand forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:18 says 'your covenant with death shall be disannulled, and your agreement with hell shall not stand'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 28:20: 'For the bed is shorter than that a man can stretch himself on it: and the covering narrower than that he can _________ himself in it.'
options: wrap
hide
cover
fold
questions.correctAnswer: wrap
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:20 states the covering is narrower than that he can 'wrap' himself in it.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:23, what does the Lord instruct us to do?
options: Give ear, and hear my voice
Build altars and offer sacrifices
Go forth and conquer
Pray without ceasing
questions.correctAnswer: Give ear, and hear my voice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:23 commands: 'Give ye ear, and hear my voice; hearken, and hear my speech.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:27, how are the fitches and cummin threshed?
options: Fitches are beaten with a staff, and cummin with a rod
Both are threshed with a threshing instrument
Both are crushed by a cart wheel
Both are bruised by horses
questions.correctAnswer: Fitches are beaten with a staff, and cummin with a rod
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:27 says 'the fitches are beaten out with a staff, and the cummin with a rod'.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and temptation to excess. Based on Isaiah 28:1-4, what biblical truth would you share about humility and self-control?
options: Pride leads to downfall and is like a fading flower.
Pride is a sign of spiritual strength and blessing.
Excess wine is a sign of God's favor.
Glory is found in worldly success and beauty.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and is like a fading flower.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:1-4 describes the crown of pride and the drunkards of Ephraim as a fading flower and a fading glory, showing that pride and excess lead to ruin rather than blessing.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:5-6 teach us about the strength God provides to those who seek to live righteously?
options: The LORD is a crown of glory and gives strength to those who judge and fight for righteousness.
God only gives strength to kings and rulers.
Strength to battle comes from human effort alone.
Righteousness is achieved by wealth and power.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is a crown of glory and gives strength to those who judge and fight for righteousness.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:5-6 states that the LORD is a crown of glory and gives a spirit of judgment and strength to those who sit in judgment and turn the battle to the gate, teaching reliance on God's power for righteous living.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their spiritual leaders seem to be failing. According to Isaiah 28:7-8, what warning does this passage give about leaders and spiritual discipline?
options: Leaders who err through strong drink cause confusion and judgment to stumble.
Spiritual leaders are infallible and never make mistakes.
Strong drink is encouraged for leaders to gain wisdom.
Leaders should keep their own counsel and not teach others.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders who err through strong drink cause confusion and judgment to stumble.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:7-8 warns that priests and prophets who err because of strong drink cause stumbling in vision and judgment, filling tables with filthiness, representing a failure in spiritual discipline and leadership.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:9-10 encourage believers to grow in spiritual understanding and discipline?
options: Spiritual teaching must be given precept upon precept, line upon line, here a little and there a little.
Spiritual knowledge comes all at once and without effort.
Believers should only focus on the big teachings and ignore the small details.
Understanding doctrine is only for mature leaders, not for all believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual teaching must be given precept upon precept, line upon line, here a little and there a little.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:9-10 highlights the progressive nature of spiritual learning, teaching that knowledge comes step by step, requiring patience and discipline in growing in faith.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 28:11-13, what lesson can be learned about the consequences of rejecting God's word?
options: Rejecting God's word causes people to be confused and fall backward, broken and snared.
Rejecting God's word brings freedom and peace.
Ignoring God's word has no real consequence.
God will send angels to force people to obey.
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God's word causes people to be confused and fall backward, broken and snared.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:11-13 teaches that those who refuse to hear God's word as given will be confused with strange tongues and fall into ruin, illustrating the danger of rejecting divine guidance.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to make compromises with evil to avoid consequences. According to Isaiah 28:14-15, what does God say about trusting in lies and falsehood for protection?
options: Making a covenant with death and hiding under lies will not protect from judgment.
Lies and falsehood provide strong refuge from trouble.
Compromise with evil is wise and accepted by God.
Avoiding consequences through deception is a sign of wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: Making a covenant with death and hiding under lies will not protect from judgment.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:14-15 condemns those who trust in lies and falsehood to escape judgment, declaring their covenant with death and hell will be disannulled and they will be overcome.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:16 teach about the foundation of faith and confidence for believers facing trials?
options: God lays a tried and precious cornerstone in Zion, and those who trust in it will not be in haste.
Faith is built on human effort and wisdom.
Believers must rely on their own strength alone.
Foundations of faith change with circumstances.
questions.correctAnswer: God lays a tried and precious cornerstone in Zion, and those who trust in it will not be in haste.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16 presents God’s foundation stone as sure and precious, offering stability and confidence to those who believe, especially during trials and uncertainty.

questions.question: A person wonders if their lies and deceptive plans will protect them from difficulties. What does Isaiah 28:17-19 teach about the outcome of such trust?
options: Hail and flood will sweep away lies and deception; the covenant with death will not stand.
Deception will secure long-lasting protection.
Lies are acceptable if they help avoid trouble.
Falsehoods strengthen personal security.
questions.correctAnswer: Hail and flood will sweep away lies and deception; the covenant with death will not stand.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:17-19 declares that God’s judgment will destroy the refuge of lies and disannul agreements with death and hell, showing the futility of trusting deception for protection.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 28:20-21, God's work includes acts that may seem strange or unexpected to accomplish His purposes.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:20-21 describes the LORD rising as in Mount Perazim and doing a strange work, indicating that God's actions, though sometimes unexpected, fulfill His sovereign purpose.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 28:22 warns that mocking God's word will only weaken the mockers and bring no harm to them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:22 warns mockers not to be scornful because their bands will be made strong and a determined consumption is coming upon the earth, showing that mocking God leads to judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 28:23-26, the plowman prepares his field by casting abroad the fitches, scattering the cummin, and casting in the principal wheat, the appointed barley, and the _____ in their place.
options: rye
corn
rice
oats
questions.correctAnswer: rye
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:25 states the plowman casts in the principal wheat, appointed barley, and the rye in their place, illustrating God's orderly and wise instruction even in agricultural work.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:27-28 teach about the importance of appropriate methods and patience in work and spiritual discipline?
options: Different crops require different treatments, and one must not rush but use the proper tools and patience.
All work is done the same way, regardless of the task.
Spiritual discipline is quick and requires no effort.
Success depends on force and haste, not patience.
questions.correctAnswer: Different crops require different treatments, and one must not rush but use the proper tools and patience.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:27-28 describes how fitches and cummin require different threshing methods and that bread corn is bruised carefully, teaching that appropriate methods and patience are essential in work and spiritual growth.

questions.question: A believer struggling with understanding God’s guidance asks how God provides wisdom in daily tasks. What does Isaiah 28:26-29 reveal about God's role in teaching discretion and counsel?
options: God teaches and instructs the plowman with wonderful counsel and excellent working.
Wisdom is only gained through human experience.
God’s counsel is hidden and not accessible to people.
Discretion comes from luck and chance.
questions.correctAnswer: God teaches and instructs the plowman with wonderful counsel and excellent working.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:26-29 shows that God instructs the plowman in discretion and gives wonderful counsel and excellent working, illustrating God’s involvement in guiding practical and spiritual wisdom.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:16-17 encourage believers to live with integrity and trust in God’s righteous judgment during trials?
options: God lays judgment and righteousness as a plummet and line, ensuring a sure foundation for the faithful.
Integrity is irrelevant during trials.
Righteous judgment is unpredictable and unfair.
Believers should rely on their own judgment alone.
questions.correctAnswer: God lays judgment and righteousness as a plummet and line, ensuring a sure foundation for the faithful.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16-17 teaches that God sets judgment and righteousness like a plummet and line, meaning He provides a firm and fair foundation for believers to trust in during trials.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to mock God’s warnings. Based on Isaiah 28:14 and 22, what counsel would you give about humility and reverence?
options: Do not be mockers; listen to the word of the LORD to avoid strengthening your own bonds of destruction.
Mocking God’s word shows spiritual maturity.
It is safe to ignore God’s warnings.
Disrespecting God has no consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be mockers; listen to the word of the LORD to avoid strengthening your own bonds of destruction.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:14 and 22 warn scornful men not to mock, because doing so strengthens their bonds and invites judgment, teaching humility and reverence.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 28.

questions.question: In Isaiah 28:16, what metaphor is used to describe the foundation laid in Zion by the Lord GOD?
options: A tried stone, a precious corner stone
A fading flower
A hasty fruit
A tempest of hail
questions.correctAnswer: A tried stone, a precious corner stone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16 uses the metaphor of a 'tried stone, a precious corner stone' as a sure foundation laid by the Lord in Zion, symbolizing stability and faith.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:7, which groups are described as erring through strong drink?
options: The priest and the prophet
The king and the warriors
The farmers and the merchants
The scribes and the elders
questions.correctAnswer: The priest and the prophet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:7 specifically states that both the priest and the prophet have erred through strong drink, affecting their vision and judgment.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Isaiah 28:10 with the repeated phrase 'precept upon precept; line upon line'?
options: Parallelism
Metaphor
Chiasm
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase in Isaiah 28:10 exemplifies parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device emphasizing gradual teaching and instruction.

questions.question: Isaiah 28:1 criticizes the 'crown of pride' and 'drunkards of Ephraim.' What does this imagery symbolize in the historical and cultural context?
options: The arrogance and moral decay of the Northern Kingdom
The strength and prosperity of Judah
The Babylonian conquerors
The faithful remnant of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The arrogance and moral decay of the Northern Kingdom
questions.explanation: The 'crown of pride' and 'drunkards of Ephraim' in Isaiah 28:1 symbolize the arrogance and spiritual decline of the Northern Kingdom, Ephraim being a chief tribe.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'stone' in Isaiah 28:16 when compared to New Testament references such as 1 Peter 2:6?
options: It foreshadows Christ as the cornerstone
It represents the temple in Jerusalem
It symbolizes the tablets of the Law
It refers to the altar of sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ as the cornerstone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16’s 'precious corner stone' is a typology later applied to Christ as the foundation of the Church in 1 Peter 2:6.

questions.question: In Isaiah 28:2, the Lord is described as a mighty force like a tempest of hail and a destroying storm. What does this imagery convey about God's judgment?
options: God’s overwhelming and inescapable judgment
God’s mercy and patience
God’s silence in times of trouble
God’s covenant promises
questions.correctAnswer: God’s overwhelming and inescapable judgment
questions.explanation: The tempest and flood imagery in Isaiah 28:2 highlights the power and inevitability of God's judgment against pride and sin.

questions.question: Isaiah 28:11 mentions God speaking with 'stammering lips and another tongue.' What does this likely refer to in the historical or prophetic context?
options: The foreign languages of invading nations
The confusion of the priests’ speech
The Hebrew language dialects
The angelic language
questions.correctAnswer: The foreign languages of invading nations
questions.explanation: The phrase in Isaiah 28:11 likely references the foreign tongues spoken by Assyrian or Babylonian conquerors, signaling judgment through incomprehensible speech.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'covenant with death, and with hell are we at agreement' in Isaiah 28:15 symbolize in terms of Israel’s political or spiritual stance?
options: A false trust in alliances and rebellion against God
A firm faith in God’s protection
A commitment to justice and righteousness
A promise of peace with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: A false trust in alliances and rebellion against God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:15 condemns Israel’s reliance on false treaties or trust in death and Sheol instead of God, illustrating spiritual rebellion.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 28:5 describes the LORD of hosts as a 'crown of glory' and 'diadem of beauty' for the faithful remnant.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:5 affirms that the LORD will be a crown of glory and beauty to the residue of His people, symbolizing honor and protection.

questions.question: In Isaiah 28:20, what do the metaphors of the bed being shorter and the covering narrower imply about the people’s situation?
options: Insufficient resources and inability to find comfort
Abundance and prosperity
Freedom and security
God’s protection and provision
questions.correctAnswer: Insufficient resources and inability to find comfort
questions.explanation: The imagery in Isaiah 28:20 suggests inadequacy and discomfort, reflecting the people's inability to find rest or security.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the agricultural imagery in Isaiah 28:24-28, particularly the detailed sowing and threshing process?
options: To illustrate God’s careful and wise instruction
To describe a festival ritual
To criticize poor farming practices
To prophesy famine
questions.correctAnswer: To illustrate God’s careful and wise instruction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:24-28 uses farming practices as a metaphor for God's precise teaching and guidance, demonstrating divine wisdom.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:21’s reference to Mount Perazim and the Valley of Gibeon relate to earlier biblical events?
options: It alludes to God's sudden and powerful acts of judgment as recorded in 2 Samuel 5
It references Moses receiving the Law on Mount Sinai
It evokes the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
It recalls the fall of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: It alludes to God's sudden and powerful acts of judgment as recorded in 2 Samuel 5
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:21 recalls God's decisive victories at Mount Perazim and Gibeon (2 Samuel 5), foreshadowing His strange and powerful acts.

questions.question: Which theme in Isaiah 28 is developed through the contrasting images of decay (fading flower) and foundation (corner stone)?
options: Judgment and hope
Wealth and poverty
War and peace
Law and grace
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and hope
questions.explanation: The chapter juxtaposes the fading glory of the proud (judgment) with the sure foundation God provides (hope), as seen in verses 1 and 16.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:13, what is the consequence for those who do not heed the Lord’s incremental teaching of 'precept upon precept'?
options: They will fall backward, be broken, snared, and taken
They will gain wisdom and understanding
They will prosper in their endeavors
They will be exalted among nations
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall backward, be broken, snared, and taken
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:13 warns that ignoring God's step-by-step instruction leads to downfall and captivity.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 28:17 mean by 'Judgment also will I lay to the line, and righteousness to the plummet' in terms of literary symbolism?
options: God will measure and establish justice with precision
God will build a house of worship
God will gather the harvest
God will send a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: God will measure and establish justice with precision
questions.explanation: The line and plummet are tools for measuring straightness, symbolizing God's precise judgment and righteousness in Isaiah 28:17.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 28 describe as the 'crown of pride' and 'drunkards of Ephraim'?
options: The leaders and people of Ephraim who are overcome with wine
The priests and prophets who teach righteousness
The humble servants of the LORD
The faithful remnant in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The leaders and people of Ephraim who are overcome with wine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:1 describes the 'crown of pride' as the drunkards of Ephraim, whose beauty is fading due to their overindulgence in wine. This highlights the sinful pride and moral failure of Ephraim's leaders, echoed in Proverbs 31:4-5 and Ephesians 5:18, which warn against drunkenness and pride.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28, how does the LORD's judgment come upon Ephraim?
options: Like a tempest of hail, a destroying storm, and a flood overflowing
Like a gentle rain that nourishes the soil
Like a whisper that brings peace
Like a fire that purifies the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Like a tempest of hail, a destroying storm, and a flood overflowing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:2 uses vivid imagery of a powerful storm and flood to describe God's judgment against Ephraim, indicating the inevitability and severity of divine wrath. Similar imagery is found in Nahum 1:3 and Psalm 18:8-9, portraying God's justice as overwhelming and unstoppable.

questions.question: What promise does Isaiah 28:5 give about the LORD of hosts for the residue of His people?
options: He will be a crown of glory and a diadem of beauty
He will abandon them to their enemies
He will hide His face from them
He will allow them to be conquered
questions.correctAnswer: He will be a crown of glory and a diadem of beauty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:5 promises that the LORD of hosts will be a glorious crown and beauty for the faithful remnant, emphasizing God’s role as protector and honor-giver. This theme resonates with Revelation 2:10 and 1 Peter 5:4 about the crown of life and glory for the faithful.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 28 say about the priests and prophets in verse 7?
options: They have erred through strong drink and stumble in judgment
They lead the people in righteousness and wisdom
They are faithful teachers of God's word
They are exalted above reproach
questions.correctAnswer: They have erred through strong drink and stumble in judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:7 condemns the priests and prophets for their drunkenness causing errors in vision and judgment, illustrating the corruption and failure of religious leaders. This is consistent with Ezekiel 22:26 and 1 Corinthians 11:29 about the dangers of unfaithful spiritual leadership.

questions.question: What is the meaning of 'precept upon precept, line upon line' in Isaiah 28:10?
options: God teaches knowledge gradually and systematically to those who are ready
God reveals everything all at once to the people
People learn independently without God's instruction
God gives confusing and contradictory messages
questions.correctAnswer: God teaches knowledge gradually and systematically to those who are ready
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:10 describes God's method of teaching in incremental steps, emphasizing patient, progressive revelation. This principle aligns with 2 Timothy 3:16 and Luke 24:27 where Scripture is taught and understood progressively.

questions.question: What consequence does Isaiah 28:13 say will happen to those who reject God's word taught 'precept upon precept'?
options: They will fall backward, be broken, snared, and taken
They will be exalted and honored
They will find peace and rest
They will be protected by God
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall backward, be broken, snared, and taken
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:13 warns that rejecting God’s clear teaching leads to judgment and destruction, illustrating the peril of hardening one's heart. This is consistent with Hebrews 3:12-13 and Proverbs 1:24-31 about consequences of rejecting divine instruction.

questions.question: In Isaiah 28:15, what false covenant do the leaders claim to have made?
options: A covenant with death and agreement with hell
A covenant of peace with God
A covenant of truth and justice
A covenant of mercy with the poor
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant with death and agreement with hell
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:15 exposes the leaders' false confidence in a covenant with death and hell, symbolizing reliance on deception rather than God’s salvation. This theme is echoed in Proverbs 14:12 and Revelation 21:8, warning against trusting in lies that lead to destruction.

questions.question: Who is the 'precious corner stone' laid in Zion according to Isaiah 28:16?
options: The Lord GOD, a sure foundation for believers
The king of Assyria
The priests of Israel
The people of Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord GOD, a sure foundation for believers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:16 prophesies the Lord GOD laying a tried and precious cornerstone in Zion, symbolizing Christ as the foundation of salvation. This is affirmed in Romans 9:33, 1 Peter 2:6-7, and Ephesians 2:20, identifying Christ as the cornerstone of the church.

questions.question: What will God lay to the line and the plummet according to Isaiah 28:17?
options: Judgment and righteousness
Mercy and forgiveness
Peace and prosperity
Confusion and chaos
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:17 states that God will apply judgment and righteousness as measuring tools, signifying His perfect justice. This aligns with Psalm 89:14 and Isaiah 11:4, which describe God's reign characterized by justice and righteousness.

questions.question: What will happen to the covenant with death and agreement with hell when the overflowing scourge passes through, according to Isaiah 28:18?
options: They will be disannulled and will not stand
They will be strengthened and honored
They will bring peace and unity
They will be ignored and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: They will be disannulled and will not stand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:18 proclaims the nullification of the leaders’ covenant with death and hell when God’s judgment comes, emphasizing the futility of trusting lies. This corresponds with Jeremiah 31:32 and Hebrews 8:13 about the new covenant replacing the old.

questions.question: How does Isaiah describe the bed and covering in Isaiah 28:20, and what does it symbolize?
options: The bed is too short and the covering too narrow, symbolizing insufficient protection
The bed is wide and the covering warm, symbolizing comfort
The bed is soft and the covering thick, symbolizing abundance
The bed is high and the covering broad, symbolizing security
questions.correctAnswer: The bed is too short and the covering too narrow, symbolizing insufficient protection
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:20 uses the imagery of a bed and covering that are too small to represent the inadequate refuge of the people’s false confidence. Similarly, Psalm 91:1-2 and Proverbs 18:10 emphasize God as the true refuge, unlike false security.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 28:21 say about the LORD's work and wrath?
options: The LORD will rise up and execute His strange work with wrath
The LORD will be silent and inactive
The LORD will forgive without judgment
The LORD will delay His justice indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will rise up and execute His strange work with wrath
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:21 describes God rising in anger to perform His decisive and unusual judgment, highlighting the certainty of divine justice. This is consistent with Exodus 15:3 and Nahum 1:2 about God's fierce wrath against sin.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 28:22, what warning is given to mockers?
options: Do not be mockers or your bands will be made strong
Mocking will be rewarded with honor
Mocking has no consequences
Mockers will be protected by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be mockers or your bands will be made strong
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:22 warns that mocking God leads to strengthening of the forces that will bring judgment, urging reverence. This aligns with Proverbs 3:34 and Galatians 6:7 about God resisting the proud but giving grace to the humble.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 28:26 describe the instruction the plowman receives?
options: God instructs him with discretion and teaches him
He works without any guidance
He follows the advice of his neighbors
He plants seeds randomly
questions.correctAnswer: God instructs him with discretion and teaches him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:26 indicates that God guides the plowman in his work, symbolizing divine wisdom in orderly creation and providence. This reflects Psalm 32:8 and James 1:5 on God’s faithful guidance in life.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 28:29 reveal about the origin of the teaching and counsel in this chapter?
options: It comes from the LORD of hosts, wonderful in counsel and excellent in working
It is the invention of human wisdom
It is a product of the priests' imagination
It is a secret known only to kings
questions.correctAnswer: It comes from the LORD of hosts, wonderful in counsel and excellent in working
questions.explanation: Isaiah 28:29 affirms that all the counsel and work described come from the LORD of hosts, highlighting God’s sovereign wisdom and power. Similar affirmations are found in Psalm 104:24 and Romans 11:33, celebrating God's inscrutable wisdom.
